title: Current accounts become new favourite target for fraudsters
text:

Fri, Jul 3, 2015, 17:57 BST - UK Markets closed Current accounts become new favourite target for fraudsters By Kyle Caldwell | Telegraph – 15 minutes ago 
Research finds at least 89 in every 10,000 applications for a current account are fraudulent 
Fraudsters are increasingly stealing identities to open current accounts, new research shows. 
Over the past year there has been an increase in imposter applications for current accounts, with at least 89 in every 10,000 applications for a current account found to be fraudulent, compared to 77 in 10,000 a year ago. 
Experian (Other OTC: EXPGF - news ) , the credit reference agency, who carried out the research, said the rise had been driven by an increase in identity fraud, which today accounts for 49pc of all attempted current account fraud. This is up from 32pc a year ago. 
The rise means current accounts have become the new favourite target for fraudsters since Experian first started collating the data eight years ago. 
Fraudulent mortgage applications, where individuals falsely inflate their income, had been the most common fraud, now been pushed into second place with 83 out of every 10,000 home loan applications deemed fraudulent, slightly up from 82 in 10,000 year-on-year. 
According to Experian the current account trend has emerged as criminals continue to probe for weaknesses in the seven day switching system, set to make it to encourage customers to move to better accounts. 
As well as offering a quick win for fraudsters withdrawing overdraft facilities, current accounts can also offer criminals a stepping stone to apply for a wider range of financial products using stolen details, the firm said. 
Nick Mothershaw, UK and Ireland (Other OTC: IRLD - news ) director of identity and fraud at Experian, said: “It is important for people to take measures to ensure their details remain their own. Knowing what your bank can and cannot ask you for will help you avoid phishing scams. Making sure sensitive mail is shredded is also important. Keeping an eye on your credit report can help you spot any suspicious activity.”
